<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Rice skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Rice</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:White,_Brown,_Red_%26_Wild_rice.jpg" title="File:White, Brown, Red &amp; Wild rice.jpg">File:White, Brown, Red &amp; Wild rice.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A mixture of brown, white, and red indica rice, also containing <a href="/wiki/Wild_rice" title="Wild rice">wild rice</a></div></div></div>
<p><b>Rice</b> is the <a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">seed</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Monocot" title="Monocot" class="mw-redirect">monocot</a> plants <i><a href="/wiki/Oryza_sativa" title="Oryza sativa">Oryza sativa</a></i> (Asian rice) or <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oryza_glaberrima&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oryza glaberrima (page does not exist)">Oryza glaberrima</a></i> (African rice). As a <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereal grain</a>, it is the most widely consumed <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a> for a large part of the world's human population, especially in Asia. It is the grain with the second-highest worldwide production, after <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">corn</a>, according to data for 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-prodstat_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodstat-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oryza_sativa_of_Kadavoor.jpg" title="File:Oryza sativa of Kadavoor.jpg">File:Oryza sativa of Kadavoor.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Oryza_sativa" title="Oryza sativa">Oryza sativa</a></i> with small <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anemophily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anemophily (page does not exist)">wind pollinated</a> flowers</div></div></div>
<p>Since a large portion of maize crops are grown for purposes other than human consumption, rice is the most important grain with regard to human nutrition and caloric intake, providing more than one fifth of the <a href="/wiki/Food_energy" title="Food energy">calories</a> consumed worldwide by humans.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Genetic evidence has shown that rice originates from a single domestication 8,200–13,500 years ago,<sup id="cite_ref-pnas1_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas1-3">[3]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/Pearl_River_(China)" title="Pearl River (China)">Pearl River</a> valley region of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nature1_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature1-4">[4]</a></sup> Previously, archaeological evidence had suggested that rice was domesticated in the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a> valley region in China.<sup id="cite_ref-pnas1_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas1-3">[3]</a></sup> From East Asia, rice spread to Southeast and South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-nature1_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature1-4">[4]</a></sup> Rice was introduced to Europe through Western Asia, and to the Americas through European colonization.
</p><p>There are many varieties of rice and culinary preferences tend to vary regionally. In some areas such as the Far East or Spain, there is a preference for softer and stickier varieties.
</p><p>Rice is normally grown as an <a href="/wiki/Annual_plant" title="Annual plant">annual plant</a>, although in tropical areas it can survive as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Perennial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Perennial (page does not exist)">perennial</a> and can produce a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ratoon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ratoon (page does not exist)">ratoon</a> crop for up to 30 years.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dead_link&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dead link (page does not exist)">Template:Dead link</a> The rice plant can grow to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall, occasionally more depending on the variety and soil fertility. It has long, slender leaves <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> broad. The small <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anemophily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anemophily (page does not exist)">wind-pollinated</a> flowers are produced in a branched arching to pendulous <a href="/wiki/Inflorescence" title="Inflorescence">inflorescence</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long. The edible seed is a grain (<a href="/wiki/Caryopsis" title="Caryopsis">caryopsis</a>) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> thick.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koeh-232.jpg" title="File:Koeh-232.jpg">File:Koeh-232.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Oryza_sativa" title="Oryza sativa">Oryza sativa</a></i>, commonly known as Asian rice</div></div></div>
<p>Rice cultivation is well-suited to countries and regions with low labor costs and high rainfall, as it is labor-intensive to cultivate and requires ample water. However, rice can be grown practically anywhere, even on a steep hill or mountain area with the use of water-controlling terrace systems. Although its parent species are native to Asia and certain parts of Africa, centuries of trade and exportation have made it commonplace in many cultures worldwide.
</p><p>The traditional method for cultivating rice is flooding the fields while, or after, setting the young seedlings. This simple method requires sound planning and servicing of the water damming and channeling, but reduces the growth of less robust weed and pest plants that have no submerged growth state, and deters <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vermin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vermin (page does not exist)">vermin</a>. While flooding is not mandatory for the cultivation of rice, all other methods of <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a> require higher effort in <a href="/wiki/Weed_control" title="Weed control">weed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pest_control" title="Pest control">pest control</a> during growth periods and a different approach for fertilizing the soil.
</p><p>The name <b><a href="/wiki/Wild_rice" title="Wild rice">wild rice</a></b> is usually used for species of the grass genus <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Zizania_(genus)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zizania (genus) (page does not exist)">Zizania</a></i>, both wild and domesticated, although the term may also be used for primitive or uncultivated varieties of <i><a href="/wiki/Oryza" title="Oryza">Oryza</a></i>.
</p>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>First used in English in the middle of the 13th century, the word "rice" derives from the <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">Old French</a> <i>ris</i>, which comes from Italian <i>riso</i>, in turn from the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <i>oriza</i>, which derives from the Greek ὄρυζα (<i>oruza</i>). The Greek word is the source of all European words (cf. Welsh <i>reis</i>, German <i>Reis</i>, Lithuanian <i>ryžiai</i>, Serbo-Croatian <i>riža</i>, Polish <i>ryż</i>, Dutch <i>rijst</i>, Hungarian <i>rizs</i>, Romanian <i>orez</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>The origin of the Greek word is unclear. It is sometimes held to be from the Tamil word அரிசி (<i>arisi</i>), or rather Old Tamil <i>arici</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-witzel_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-witzel-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> However, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhadriraju_Krishnamurti&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bhadriraju Krishnamurti (page does not exist)">Krishnamurti</a><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> disagrees with the notion that Old Tamil <i>arici</i> is the source of the Greek term, and proposes that it was borrowed from descendants of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Proto-Dravidian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Proto-Dravidian language (page does not exist)">Proto-Dravidian</a> *<i>wariñci</i> instead. Mayrhofer<sup id="cite_ref-EWA_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWA-12">[12]</a></sup> suggests that the immediate source of the Greek word is to be sought in Old Iranian words of the types *<i>vrīz-</i> or *<i>vrinj-</i>, but these are ultimately traced back to Indo-Aryan (as in <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <i>vrīhí-</i>) and subsequently to Dravidian by Witzel and others.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Preparation_as_food">Preparation as food</span></h2>
<div id="white_rice"></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritional_value&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritional value (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritional value</a>
The seeds of the rice plant are first milled using a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_huller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice huller (page does not exist)">rice huller</a> to remove the <a href="/wiki/Chaff" title="Chaff">chaff</a> (the outer husks of the grain). At this point in the process, the product is called <a href="/wiki/Brown_rice" title="Brown rice">brown rice</a>. The milling may be continued, removing the <a href="/wiki/Bran" title="Bran">bran</a>, <i>i.e.</i>, the rest of the husk and the <a href="/wiki/Cereal_germ" title="Cereal germ">germ</a>, thereby creating <a href="/wiki/White_rice" title="White rice">white rice</a>. White rice, which keeps longer, lacks some important nutrients; moreover, in a limited diet which does not supplement the rice, brown rice helps to prevent the <a href="/wiki/Disease" title="Disease">disease</a> <a href="/wiki/Beriberi" title="Beriberi">beriberi</a>.
</p><p>Either by hand or in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_polisher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice polisher (page does not exist)">rice polisher</a>, white rice may be buffed with glucose or <a href="/wiki/Talc" title="Talc">talc</a> powder (often called polished rice, though this term may also refer to white rice in general), <a href="/wiki/Parboiled_rice" title="Parboiled rice">parboiled</a>, or processed into flour. White rice may also be enriched by adding nutrients, especially those lost during the milling process. While the cheapest method of enriching involves adding a powdered blend of nutrients that will easily wash off (in the United States, rice which has been so treated requires a label warning against rinsing), more sophisticated methods apply nutrients directly to the grain, coating the grain with a water-insoluble substance which is resistant to washing.
</p><p>In some countries, a popular form, <a href="/wiki/Parboiled_rice" title="Parboiled rice">parboiled rice</a>, is subjected to a steaming or parboiling process while still a brown rice grain. This causes nutrients from the outer husk, especially <a href="/wiki/Thiamine" title="Thiamine">thiamine</a>, to move into the grain itself. The parboil process causes a gelatinisation of the starch in the grains. The grains become less brittle, and the color of the milled grain changes from white to yellow. The rice is then dried, and can then be milled as usual or used as brown rice. Milled parboiled rice is nutritionally superior to standard milled rice. Parboiled rice has an additional benefit in that it does not stick to the pan during cooking, as happens when cooking regular white rice. This type of rice is eaten in parts of India and countries of West Africa are also accustomed to consuming parboiled rice.
</p><p>Despite the hypothetical health risks of talc (such as stomach cancer),<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> talc-coated rice remains the norm in some countries due to its attractive shiny appearance, but it has been banned in some, and is no longer widely used in others (such as the United States). Even where talc is not used, glucose, starch, or other coatings may be used to improve the appearance of the grains.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rice_bran" title="Rice bran" class="mw-redirect">Rice bran</a>, called <i>nika</i> in Japan, is a valuable commodity in Asia and is used for many daily needs. It is a moist, oily inner layer which is heated to produce oil. It is also used as a pickling bed in making <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nukazuke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nukazuke (page does not exist)">rice bran pickles</a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Takuan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Takuan (page does not exist)">takuan</a></i>.
</p><p>Raw rice may be ground into flour for many uses, including making many kinds of beverages, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Amazake" title="Amazake">amazake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horchata" title="Horchata">horchata</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Rice_milk" title="Rice milk">rice milk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rice_wine" title="Rice wine">rice wine</a>. Rice flour does not contain <a href="/wiki/Gluten" title="Gluten">gluten</a>, so is suitable for people on a <a href="/wiki/Gluten-free_diet" title="Gluten-free diet">gluten-free diet</a>. Rice may also be made into various types of <a href="/wiki/Noodle" title="Noodle">noodles</a>. Raw, wild, or brown rice may also be consumed by <a href="/wiki/Raw_foodism" title="Raw foodism">raw-foodist</a> or <a href="/wiki/Fruitarians" title="Fruitarians" class="mw-redirect">fruitarians</a> if soaked and <a href="/wiki/Sprouting" title="Sprouting">sprouted</a> (usually a week to 30 days – gaba rice).
</p><p>Processed rice seeds must be boiled or steamed before eating. Boiled rice may be further fried in <a href="/wiki/Cooking_oil" title="Cooking oil">cooking oil</a> or butter (known as <a href="/wiki/Fried_rice" title="Fried rice">fried rice</a>), or beaten in a tub to make <i><a href="/wiki/Mochi" title="Mochi">mochi</a></i>.
</p><p>Rice is a good source of protein and a staple food in many parts of the world, but it is not a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete protein</a>: it does not contain all of the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acids" title="Essential amino acids" class="mw-redirect">essential amino acids</a> in sufficient amounts for good health, and should be combined with other sources of protein, such as nuts, seeds, beans, fish, or meat.<sup id="cite_ref-Protein_content_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Protein_content-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rice, like other cereal <a href="/wiki/Caryopsis" title="Caryopsis">grains</a>, can be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Puffed_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puffed rice (page does not exist)">puffed (or popped)</a>. This process takes advantage of the grains' water content and typically involves heating grains in a special chamber. Further puffing is sometimes accomplished by processing puffed pellets in a low-<a href="/wiki/Pressure" title="Pressure">pressure</a> chamber. The <a href="/wiki/Ideal_gas_law" title="Ideal gas law">ideal gas law</a> means either lowering the local pressure or raising the water temperature results in an increase in <a href="/wiki/Volume" title="Volume">volume</a> prior to water <a href="/wiki/Evaporation" title="Evaporation">evaporation</a>, resulting in a puffy <a href="/w/index.php?title=Texture_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Texture (food) (page does not exist)">texture</a>. Bulk raw rice density is about 0.9 g/cm³. It decreases to less than one-tenth that when puffed.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooking">Cooking</span></h2>
<p>The many varieties of rice, for many purposes, are distinguished as long-, medium-, and short-grain rices. The grains of fragrant long-grain rice (high <a href="/wiki/Amylose" title="Amylose">amylose</a>) tend to remain intact after cooking; medium-grain rice (high <a href="/wiki/Amylopectin" title="Amylopectin">amylopectin</a>) becomes more sticky. Medium-grain rice is used for sweet dishes, for <i><a href="/wiki/Risotto" title="Risotto">risotto</a></i> in Italy and many rice dishes, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Arr%C3%B2s_negre" title="Arròs negre">arròs negre</a></i>, in Spain. Some varieties of long-grain rice are high in <a href="/wiki/Amylopectin" title="Amylopectin">amylopectin</a>, these are generally known as Thai Sticky rice, usually steamed.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> A stickier medium-grain rice is used for <i><a href="/wiki/Sushi" title="Sushi">sushi</a></i>; the stickiness lets the rice be moulded into a solid shape. Short-grain rice is often used for <a href="/wiki/Rice_pudding" title="Rice pudding">rice pudding</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kome.JPG" title="File:Kome.JPG">File:Kome.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Milled to unmilled rice, from left to right, <a href="/w/index.php?title=En:White_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="En:White rice (page does not exist)">white rice</a> <i>(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese rice (page does not exist)">Japanese rice</a>)</i>, rice with <a href="/w/index.php?title=En:Cereal_germ&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="En:Cereal germ (page does not exist)">germ</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=En:Brown_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="En:Brown rice (page does not exist)">brown rice</a></div></div></div>
<p>Rice is cooked by <a href="/wiki/Boiling" title="Boiling">boiling</a> or <a href="/wiki/Steaming" title="Steaming">steaming</a>, and absorbs water during cooking. It can be cooked in just as much water as it absorbs (the absorption method), or in a large quantity of water which is drained before serving (the rapid-boil method).<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Electric <a href="/wiki/Rice_cooker" title="Rice cooker">rice cookers</a>, popular in Asia and Latin America, simplify the process of cooking rice. Rice (or any other grain) is sometimes quickly fried in oil or fat before boiling (for example <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saffron_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saffron rice (page does not exist)">saffron rice</a> or <a href="/wiki/Risotto" title="Risotto">risotto</a>); this makes the cooked rice less sticky, and is a cooking style commonly called <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a> by American chefs or <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Dam-pukhtak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dam-pukhtak (page does not exist)">Dam-pukhtak</a>) in India, Pakistan, and Iran.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rice_Animation.gif" title="File:Rice Animation.gif">File:Rice Animation.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A: Rice with <a href="/wiki/Chaff" title="Chaff">chaff</a><br />B: <a href="/wiki/Brown_rice" title="Brown rice">Brown rice</a><br />C: Rice with <a href="/wiki/Cereal_germ" title="Cereal germ">germ</a><br />D: <a href="/wiki/White_rice" title="White rice">White rice</a> with <a href="/wiki/Bran" title="Bran">bran</a> <a href="/wiki/Crop_residue" title="Crop residue">residue</a><br />E: Musenmai (Japanese: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ja:%E7%84%A1%E6%B4%97%E7%B1%B3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ja:無洗米 (page does not exist)">無洗米</a>), "Polished and ready to boil rice", literally, non-wash rice<br />(1): <a href="/wiki/Chaff" title="Chaff">Chaff</a><br />(2): <a href="/wiki/Bran" title="Bran">Bran</a><br />(3): Bran <a href="/wiki/Crop_residue" title="Crop residue">residue</a><br />(4): <a href="/wiki/Cereal_germ" title="Cereal germ">Cereal germ</a><br />(5): <a href="/wiki/Endosperm" title="Endosperm">Endosperm</a></div></div></div>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab cuisine</a>, rice is an ingredient of many soups and dishes with fish, poultry, and other types of meat. It is also used to stuff vegetables or is wrapped in grape leaves (<a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">dolma</a>). When combined with milk, sugar, and honey, it is used to make desserts. In some regions, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tabaristan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tabaristan (page does not exist)">Tabaristan</a>, bread is made using rice flour. Medieval Islamic texts spoke of medical uses for the plant.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rice may also be made into <a href="/wiki/Congee" title="Congee">congee</a> (also called rice porridge, fawrclaab, okayu, Xifan, jook, or rice gruel) by adding more water than usual, so that the cooked rice is saturated with water, usually to the point that it disintegrates. Rice porridge is commonly eaten as a breakfast food, and is also a traditional food for the sick.
</p><p>Rice may be soaked prior to cooking, which saves fuel, decreases cooking time, minimizes exposure to high temperature and thus decreases the stickiness of the rice. For some <a href="/wiki/Variety_(botany)" title="Variety (botany)">varieties</a>, soaking improves the texture of the cooked rice by increasing expansion of the grains.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Instant_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Instant rice (page does not exist)">Instant rice</a> differs from <a href="/wiki/Parboiled_rice" title="Parboiled rice">parboiled rice</a> in that it is milled, fully cooked and then dried. There is a significant degradation in taste and texture.
</p><p>A nutritionally superior method of preparing brown rice known as <b>GABA Rice</b> or GBR (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Germinated_brown_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germinated brown rice (page does not exist)">germinated brown rice</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> may be used. This involves soaking washed brown rice for 20 hours in warm water (38 °C or 100 °F) prior to cooking it. This stimulates <a href="/wiki/Germination" title="Germination">germination</a>, which activates various <a href="/wiki/Enzymes" title="Enzymes" class="mw-redirect">enzymes</a> in the rice. By this method, a result of research carried out for the United Nations <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Year_of_Rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Year of Rice (page does not exist)">International Year of Rice</a>, it is possible to obtain a more complete <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acid</a> profile, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gamma-aminobutyric_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gamma-aminobutyric acid (page does not exist)">GABA</a>.
</p><p>Rice flour and <a href="/wiki/Starch" title="Starch">starch</a> often are used in <a href="/wiki/Batter_(cooking)" title="Batter (cooking)">batters</a> and breadings to increase crispiness.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition_and_health">Nutrition and health</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrients_and_the_nutritional_importance_of_rice">Nutrients and the nutritional importance of rice</span></h3>
<p>Rice is the staple food of over half the world's population. It is the predominant dietary energy source for 17 countries in Asia and the Pacific, 9 countries in North and South America and 8 countries in Africa. Rice provides 20% of the world’s dietary energy supply, while wheat supplies 19% and maize (corn) 5%.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>A detailed analysis of nutrient content of rice suggests that the nutrition value of rice varies based on a number of factors. It depends on the strain of rice, that is between white, brown, black, red and purple varieties of rice – each prevalent in different parts of the world. It also depends on nutrient quality of the soil rice is grown in, whether and how the rice is polished or processed, the manner it is enriched, and how it is prepared before consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>An illustrative comparison between white and brown rice of protein quality, mineral and vitamin quality, carbohydrate and fat quality suggests that neither is a complete nutrition source. Between the two, there is a significant difference in fiber content and minor differences in other nutrients.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>Brilliantly colored rice strains, such as purple rice, derive their color from anthocyanins and tocols. Scientific studies suggest that these color pigments have antioxidant properties that may be useful to human health. In purple rice bran, hydrophilic antioxidants are in greater quantity and have higher free radical scavenging activity than lipophilic antioxidants. Anthocyanins and γ-tocols in purple rice are largely located in the inner portion of purple rice bran.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>Comparative nutrition studies on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Red_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Red rice (page does not exist)">red</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black rice (page does not exist)">black</a> and white varieties of rice suggest that pigments in red and black rice varieties may offer nutritional benefits. Red or black rice consumption was found to reduce or retard the progression of atherosclerotic plaque development, induced by dietary cholesterol, in mammals. White rice consumption offered no similar benefits, and the study claims this to be due to absent antioxidants in red and black varieties of rice.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Comparison_of_rice_to_other_major_staple_foods">Comparison of rice to other major staple foods</span></h3>
<p>The table below shows the nutrient content of major staple foods in a raw form. Raw grains, however, are not edible and can not be digested. These must be <a href="/wiki/Sprouting" title="Sprouting">sprouted</a>, or prepared and cooked for human consumption. In sprouted and cooked form, the relative nutritional and anti-nutritional contents of each of these grains is remarkably different from that of raw form of these grains reported in this table.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Comparison_of_major_staple_foods&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Comparison of major staple foods (page does not exist)">Template:Comparison of major staple foods</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arsenic_concerns">Arsenic concerns</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Rice and rice products contain <a href="/wiki/Arsenic" title="Arsenic">arsenic</a>, a known poison and <a href="/wiki/List_of_IARC_Group_1_carcinogens" title="List of IARC Group 1 carcinogens">Group 1 carcinogen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EFSA2009_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EFSA2009-25">[25]</a></sup> There is no safe level of arsenic, but, as of 2012, a limit of 10 parts per billion has been established in the United States for drinking water, twice the level of 5 parts per billion originally proposed by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="United States Environmental Protection Agency">EPA</a>. Consumption of one serving of some varieties of rice gives more exposure to arsenic than consumption of 1 liter of water that contains 5 parts per billion arsenic; however, the amount of arsenic in rice varies widely with the greatest concentration in brown rice and rice grown on land formerly used to grow cotton; in the United States, Arkansas, Louisiana, Missouri, and Texas.<sup id="cite_ref-CR1112_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CR1112-26">[26]</a></sup> The U.S. <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">Food and Drug Administration</a> (FDA) is studying this issue, but has not established a limit.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> China has set a limit of 150 ppb for arsenic in rice.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>White rice grown in Arkansas, Louisiana, Missouri, and Texas, which account for 76 percent of American-produced rice had higher levels of arsenic than other regions of the world studied, possibly because of past use of arsenic-based pesticides to control cotton weevils.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Rice from Thailand and India contain the least arsenic among rice varieties in one study.<sup id="cite_ref-cpotera_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cpotera-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bacillus_cereus">Bacillus cereus</span></h3>
<p>Cooked rice can contain <i><a href="/wiki/Bacillus_cereus" title="Bacillus cereus">Bacillus cereus</a></i> spores, which produce an <a href="/wiki/Emetic" title="Emetic" class="mw-redirect">emetic</a> toxin when left at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. When storing cooked rice for use the next day, rapid cooling is advised to reduce the risk of toxin production.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> One of the <a href="/wiki/Enterotoxin" title="Enterotoxin">enterotoxins</a> produced by <i>Bacillus cereus</i> is heat-resistant; reheating contaminated rice kills the bacteria, but does not destroy the toxin already present.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Rice-growing_environments">Rice-growing environments</span></h2>
<p>Rice can be grown in different environments, depending upon water availability.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Generally, rice does not thrive in a waterlogged area, yet it can survive and grow herein<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> and it can also survive flooding.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol>
<li> <b>Lowland, rainfed</b>, which is drought prone, favors medium depth; waterlogged, submergence, and flood prone
</li>
<li><b> Lowland, irrigated</b>, grown in both the wet season and the dry season
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Deep_water_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deep water rice (page does not exist)">Deep water</a></b> or floating rice
</li>
<li> <b>Coastal Wetland</b>
</li>
<li> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Upland_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Upland rice (page does not exist)">Upland rice</a></b> is also known as <b>Ghaiya rice</b>, well known for its drought tolerance<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</li>
</ol>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_domestication_and_cultivation">History of domestication and cultivation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ambositra_04.jpg" title="File:Ambositra 04.jpg">File:Ambositra 04.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rice crop in Madagascar</div></div></div>
<p>African rice has been cultivated for 3500 years. Between 1500 and 800 BC, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oryza_glaberrima&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oryza glaberrima (page does not exist)">Oryza glaberrima</a></i> propagated from its original centre, the <a href="/wiki/Niger_River" title="Niger River">Niger River</a> <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">delta</a>, and extended to Senegal. However, it never developed far from its original region. Its cultivation even declined in favour of the Asian species, which was introduced to East Africa early in the common era and spread westward.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> African rice helped Africa conquer its famine of 1203.<sup id="cite_ref-National_Academies_Press_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nihonbashi_bridge_in_Edo.jpg" title="File:Nihonbashi bridge in Edo.jpg">File:Nihonbashi bridge in Edo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rice broker in 1820's Japan of the <a href="/wiki/Edo_period" title="Edo period">Edo period</a> (<i>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=36_Views_of_Mount_Fuji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="36 Views of Mount Fuji (page does not exist)">36 Views of Mount Fuji</a>"</i> <a href="/wiki/Hokusai" title="Hokusai">Hokusai</a>)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Terrace_field_yunnan_china.jpg" title="File:Terrace field yunnan china.jpg">File:Terrace field yunnan china.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Aerial view of <a href="/wiki/Terrace_(agriculture)" title="Terrace (agriculture)">terrace</a> rice fields in <a href="/wiki/Yuanyang_County,_Yunnan" title="Yuanyang County, Yunnan">Yuanyang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> Province, southern <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dili_Reisfelder.jpg" title="File:Dili Reisfelder.jpg">File:Dili Reisfelder.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rice fields in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dili_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dili District (page does not exist)">Dili</a>/<a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Timor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Timor (page does not exist)">East Timor</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BeFunky_Chromatic_1.jpg" title="File:BeFunky Chromatic 1.jpg">File:BeFunky Chromatic 1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Indian women separating rice from straw</div></div></div>
<p>There have been plenty of debates on the origins of the domesticated rice. Genetic evidence published in the <i><a href="/wiki/Proceedings_of_the_National_Academy_of_Sciences_of_the_United_States_of_America" title="Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America">Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America</a></i> (PNAS) shows that all forms of Asian rice, both <i>indica</i> and <i>japonica</i>, spring from a single domestication that occurred 8,200–13,500 years ago in China of the wild rice <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oryza_rufipogon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oryza rufipogon (page does not exist)">Oryza rufipogon</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-pnas1_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas1-3">[3]</a></sup> A 2012 study published in <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>, through a map of rice genome variation, indicated that the domestication of rice occurred in the <a href="/wiki/Pearl_River_(China)" title="Pearl River (China)">Pearl River</a> valley region of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. From East Asia, rice was spread to South and Southeast Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-nature1_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature1-4">[4]</a></sup>
Before this research, the commonly accepted view, based on archaeological evidence, is that rice was first domesticated in the region of the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a> valley in China.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-harris_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harris-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Morphological studies of rice <a href="/wiki/Phytolith" title="Phytolith">phytoliths</a> from the Diaotonghuan archaeological site clearly show the transition from the collection of wild rice to the cultivation of domesticated rice. The large number of wild rice phytoliths at the Diaotonghuan level dating from 12,000–11,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">BP</a> indicates that wild rice collection was part of the local means of subsistence. Changes in the morphology of Diaotonghuan phytoliths dating from 10,000–8,000 BP show that rice had by this time been domesticated.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Soon afterwards the two major varieties of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indica_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indica rice (page does not exist)">indica</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japonica_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japonica rice (page does not exist)">japonica</a> rice were being grown in Central China.<sup id="cite_ref-harris_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harris-39">[39]</a></sup> In the late 3rd millennium BC, there was a rapid expansion of rice cultivation into mainland Southeast Asia and westwards across India and Nepal.<sup id="cite_ref-harris_39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harris-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003, Korean archaeologists claimed to have discovered the world's oldest domesticated rice.<sup id="cite_ref-rice_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice-41">[41]</a></sup> Their 15,000-year old age challenges the accepted view that rice cultivation originated in China about 12,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-rice_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice-41">[41]</a></sup> These findings were received by academia with strong skepticism,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> and the results and their publicizing has been cited as being driven by a combination of nationalist and regional interests.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> In 2011, a combined effort by the <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New York University (page does not exist)">New York University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis" title="Washington University in St. Louis">Washington University in St. Louis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Purdue_University" title="Purdue University">Purdue University</a> has provided the strongest evidence yet that there is only one single origin of domesticated rice, in the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_Valley" title="Yangtze Valley" class="mw-redirect">Yangtze Valley</a> of China.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest remains of the grain in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a> have been found in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Indo-Gangetic Plain</a> and date from 7000–6000 BC though the earliest widely accepted date for cultivated rice is placed at around 3000–2500 BC with findings in regions belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a>. Perennial wild rices still grow in <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a> and Nepal. It seems to have appeared around 1400 BC in southern India after its domestication in the northern plains.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} It then spread to all the fertile alluvial plains watered by rivers. Cultivation and cooking methods are thought to have spread to the west rapidly and by medieval times, southern Europe saw the introduction of rice as a hearty grain.
</p><p>According to Zohary and Hopf (2000, p.&#160;91), <i>O. sativa</i> was recovered from a grave at <a href="/wiki/Susa" title="Susa">Susa</a> in Iran (dated to the 1st century AD) at one end of the ancient world, another domestication of rice in South Asia.
</p><p>Today, the majority of all rice produced comes from China, India, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Vietnam, Thailand, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Myanmar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Myanmar (page does not exist)">Myanmar</a>, Pakistan, Philippines, and Japan. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian people (page does not exist)">Asian</a> farmers still account for 92% of the world's total rice production.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sri_Lanka">Sri Lanka</span></h4>
<p>Rice is the staple food amongst all the ethnic groups in <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agriculture_in_Sri_Lanka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agriculture in Sri Lanka (page does not exist)">Agriculture in Sri Lanka</a> mainly depends on the rice cultivation. Rice production is acutely dependent on rainfall and government supply necessity of water through irrigation channels throughout the cultivation seasons. The principal cultivation season, known as "Maha", is from October to March and the subsidiary cultivation season, known as "Yala", is from April to September. During Maha season, there is usually enough water to sustain the cultivation of all rice fields, nevertheless in Yala season there is only enough water for cultivation of half of the land extent.
</p><p>Traditional rice varieties are now making a comeback with the recent interest in green foods.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Thailand">Thailand</span></h4>
<p>Rice is the main export of Thailand, especially the white jasmine rice 105 (Dok Mali 105).<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Thailand has a large number of rice varieties, 3,500 kinds with different characters, and 5 kinds of wild rice cultivates.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> In each region of the country there are different rice seed types. Their use depends on weather, atmosphere, and topography.<sup id="cite_ref-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._44.2C_1998_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._44.2C_1998-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Northern_region">Northern region</span></h5>
<p>The northern region has both low lands and high lands. The farmers’ usual crop is non-glutinous rice <sup id="cite_ref-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._44.2C_1998_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._44.2C_1998-48">[48]</a></sup> such as Niew Sun Pah Tong rice seeds. This rice is naturally protected from leaf disease, and the paddy has 
a brown color.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Northeastern_region">Northeastern region</span></h5>
<p>The northeastern region has a large area, where farmers can cultivate about 36 million square meters of rice. Although most of them are plains and dry areas,<sup id="cite_ref-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._45.2C_1998_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._45.2C_1998-50">[50]</a></sup> they can grow the white jasmine rice 105 which is the most famous Thai rice. The white jasmine rice was developed in Chonburi province first and after that it was grown in many areas in the country but the rice from this region has a high quality, because it's softer, whiter and more fragrant.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> This rice can resist drought, acidic soil, and alkaline soil.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Central_region">Central region</span></h5>
<p>The central region is mostly composed of plains. Most farmers grow Jao rice.<sup id="cite_ref-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._45.2C_1998_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_ecology_of_life.2C_p._45.2C_1998-50">[50]</a></sup> For example the Pathum Thani 1 rice which has qualities similar to the white jasmine 105 rice. Their paddy has the color of thatch and their cooked rice has fragrant grains also.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="South_region">South region</span></h5>
<p>Most farmers transplant around boundaries to the flood of plain or plain between mountains. Farming is the region is slower than other regions because the rainy season comes late.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> The popular rice varieties in this area are the Leb Nok Pattani seeds, a type of Jao rice. Their paddy has the color of thatch and it can be processed to make noodles.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Companion_plant">Companion plant</span></h4>
<p>One of the earliest known examples of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Companion_plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Companion plant (page does not exist)">companion planting</a> is the growing of rice with <a href="/wiki/Azolla" title="Azolla">Azolla</a>, the mosquito fern, which covers the top of a fresh rice paddy's water, blocking out any competing plants, as well as fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere for the rice to use. The rice is planted when it is tall enough to poke out above the azolla. This method has been used for at least a thousand years.
</p><p><br />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_East">Middle East</span></h3>
<p>Rice was grown in some areas of southern Iraq. With the rise of Islam it moved north to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nisibin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nisibin (page does not exist)">Nisibin</a>, the southern shores of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caspian_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caspian Sea (page does not exist)">Caspian Sea</a>(Iran)<sup id="cite_ref-pazuki_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pazuki-56">[56]</a></sup> and then beyond the Muslim world into the valley of the <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga" class="mw-redirect">Volga</a>. In Egypt, rice is mainly grown in the Nile Delta. In Israel, rice came to be grown in the Jordan Valley. Rice is also grown in Saudi Arabia at Al-hasa Oasis and in Yemen.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Europe">Europe</span></h3>
<p>Rice was known to the Classical world, being imported from Egypt, and perhaps west Asia. It was known to Greece by returning soldiers from Alexander the Great's military expedition to Asia. Large deposits of rice from the first century A.D. have been found in Roman camps in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Moors</a> brought Asiatic rice to the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> in the 10th century. Records indicate it was grown in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valencian_Community&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valencian Community (page does not exist)">Valencia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Majorca" title="Majorca">Majorca</a>. In Majorca, rice cultivation seems to have stopped after the Christian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reconquesta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reconquesta (page does not exist)">conquest</a>, although historians are not certain.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Muslims also brought rice to <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a>, where it was an important crop<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-57">[57]</a></sup> long before it is noted in the plain of <a href="/wiki/Pisa" title="Pisa">Pisa</a> (1468) or in the Lombard plain (1475), where its cultivation was promoted by <a href="/wiki/Ludovico_Sforza" title="Ludovico Sforza">Ludovico Sforza</a>, Duke of Milan, and demonstrated in his model farms.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the 15th century, rice spread throughout Italy and then France, later propagating to all the continents during the age of European exploration.
</p><p>In European Russia, a short-grain, starchy rice similar to the Italian varieties, has been grown in the <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a>, and known in Russia as "Kuban Rice" or "Krasnodar Rice". In the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a> several <i>japonica</i> cultivars are grown in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Primorye&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Primorye (page does not exist)">Primorye</a> around the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Khanka_lake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khanka lake (page does not exist)">Khanka lake</a>. Increasing scale of rice production in the region has recently brought criticism towards growers' alleged bad practices in regards to the environment.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Caribbean_and_Latin_America">Caribbean and Latin America</span></h3>
<p>Rice is not native to the Americas but was introduced to Latin America and the Caribbean by <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">European colonizers</a> at an early date with <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish colonizers</a> introducing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian rice (page does not exist)">Asian rice</a> to Mexico in the 1520s at <a href="/wiki/Veracruz" title="Veracruz">Veracruz</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> and their African slaves introducing it at about the same time to <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Colonial Brazil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-slaveryinamerica.org_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slaveryinamerica.org-60">[60]</a></sup> Recent scholarship suggests that <a href="/wiki/African_slave_trade" title="African slave trade" class="mw-redirect">enslaved Africans</a> played an active role in the establishment of rice in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New World (page does not exist)">New World</a> and that <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African rice (page does not exist)">African rice</a> was an important crop from an early period.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Varieties of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_and_bean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice and bean (page does not exist)">rice and bean</a> dishes that were a staple dish along the peoples of West Africa remained a staple among their descendants subjected to <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_Spanish_New_World_colonies" title="Slavery in the Spanish New World colonies">slavery in the Spanish New World colonies</a>, Brazil and elsewhere in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-National_Academies_Press_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_agriculture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of agriculture (page does not exist)">Native Americans</a> of what is now the Eastern United States may have practiced extensive agriculture with forms of wild rice.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MansfieldWinnowingBarn.jpg" title="File:MansfieldWinnowingBarn.jpg">File:MansfieldWinnowingBarn.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">South Carolina rice plantation, showing a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Winnowing_barn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Winnowing barn (page does not exist)">Winnowing barn</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mansfield_Plantation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mansfield Plantation (page does not exist)">Mansfield Plantation</a>, Georgetown)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1694, rice arrived in <a href="/wiki/South_Carolina" title="South Carolina">South Carolina</a>, probably originating from Madagascar.<sup id="cite_ref-slaveryinamerica.org_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slaveryinamerica.org-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, <a href="/wiki/Colonial_history_of_the_United_States" title="Colonial history of the United States">colonial</a> South Carolina and <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a> grew and amassed great wealth from the slave labor obtained from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senegambia_(geography)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senegambia (geography) (page does not exist)">Senegambia</a> area of West Africa and from coastal Sierra Leone. At the port of Charleston, through which 40% of all American slave imports passed, slaves from this region of Africa brought the highest prices due to their prior knowledge of rice culture, which was put to use on the many rice <a href="/wiki/Plantation" title="Plantation">plantations</a> around <a href="/wiki/Georgetown,_South_Carolina" title="Georgetown, South Carolina">Georgetown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina" title="Charleston, South Carolina">Charleston</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia" title="Savannah, Georgia">Savannah</a>.
</p><p>From the enslaved Africans, plantation owners learned how to dyke the <a href="/wiki/Marsh" title="Marsh">marshes</a> and periodically flood the fields. At first the rice was laboriously milled by hand using large mortars and pestles made of wood, then winnowed in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muhlenbergia_filipes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muhlenbergia filipes (page does not exist)">sweetgrass</a> <a href="/wiki/Basket" title="Basket">baskets</a> (the making of which was another skill brought by slaves from Africa). The invention of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_mill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice mill (page does not exist)">rice mill</a> increased profitability of the crop, and the addition of water power for the mills in 1787 by <a href="/wiki/Millwright" title="Millwright">millwright</a> Jonathan Lucas was another step forward.
</p><p>Rice culture in the southeastern U.S. became less profitable with the loss of slave labor after the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a>, and it finally died out just after the turn of the 20th century. Today, people can visit the only remaining rice plantation in South Carolina that still has the original <a href="/w/index.php?title=Winnowing_barn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Winnowing barn (page does not exist)">winnowing barn</a> and rice mill from the mid-19th century at the historic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mansfield_Plantation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mansfield Plantation (page does not exist)">Mansfield Plantation</a> in <a href="/wiki/Georgetown,_South_Carolina" title="Georgetown, South Carolina">Georgetown, South Carolina</a>. The predominant strain of rice in the Carolinas was from Africa and was known as "Carolina Gold." The <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivar</a> has been preserved and there are current attempts to reintroduce it as a commercially grown crop.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the southern United States, rice has been grown in southern <a href="/wiki/Arkansas" title="Arkansas">Arkansas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, and east Texas since the mid-19th century. Many <a href="/wiki/Cajun" title="Cajun">Cajun</a> farmers grew rice in wet marshes and low lying prairies where they could also farm <a href="/wiki/Crayfish" title="Crayfish">crayfish</a> when the fields were flooded.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> In recent years rice production has risen in North America, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River_Delta" title="Mississippi River Delta">Mississippi River Delta</a> areas in the states of <a href="/wiki/Arkansas" title="Arkansas">Arkansas</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mississippi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mississippi (page does not exist)">Mississippi</a>.
</p><p>Rice cultivation began in California during the <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">California Gold Rush</a>, when an estimated 40,000 Chinese laborers immigrated to the state and grew small amounts of the grain for their own consumption. However, commercial production began only in 1912 in the town of <a href="/wiki/Richvale,_California" title="Richvale, California">Richvale</a> in <a href="/wiki/Butte_County,_California" title="Butte County, California">Butte County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Historic_Richvale_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Historic_Richvale-64">[64]</a></sup> By 2006, California produced the second largest rice crop in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-CRC_region_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRC_region-65">[65]</a></sup> after Arkansas, with production concentrated in six counties north of <a href="/wiki/Sacramento,_California" title="Sacramento, California">Sacramento</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CRC_economic_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRC_economic-66">[66]</a></sup> Unlike the Mississippi Delta region, California's production is dominated by short- and medium-grain <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese rice (page does not exist)"><i>japonica</i></a> varieties, including cultivars developed for the local climate such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Calrose&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calrose (page does not exist)">Calrose</a>, which makes up as much as 85% of the state's crop.<sup id="cite_ref-CRC_medium_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRC_medium-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>References to wild rice in the Americas are to the unrelated <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Zizania_palustris&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zizania palustris (page does not exist)">Zizania palustris</a></i>
</p><p>More than 100 varieties of rice are commercially produced primarily in six states (Arkansas, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, and California) in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-States_Department_of_Agriculture_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-States_Department_of_Agriculture-68">[68]</a></sup>
According to estimates for the 2006 crop year, rice production in the U.S. is valued at $1.88 billion, approximately half of which is expected to be <a href="/wiki/Exported" title="Exported" class="mw-redirect">exported</a>.
The U.S. provides about 12% of world rice trade.<sup id="cite_ref-States_Department_of_Agriculture_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-States_Department_of_Agriculture-68">[68]</a></sup>
The majority of domestic utilization of U.S. rice is direct food use (58%), while 16% is used in each of processed foods and beer. 10% is found in pet food.<sup id="cite_ref-States_Department_of_Agriculture_68-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-States_Department_of_Agriculture-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia">Australia</span></h3>
<p>Rice was one of the earliest crops planted in Australia by British <a href="/wiki/Settlers" title="Settlers" class="mw-redirect">settlers</a>, who had experience with rice plantations in the Americas and India.
</p><p>Although attempts to grow rice in the well-watered north of Australia have been made for many years, they have consistently failed because of inherent iron and <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a> toxicities in the soils and destruction by <a href="/wiki/Pest_(organism)" title="Pest (organism)">pests</a>.
</p><p>In the 1920s it was seen as a possible <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irrigation_in_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irrigation in Australia (page does not exist)">irrigation</a> crop on soils within the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Murray-Darling_Basin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Murray-Darling Basin (page does not exist)">Murray-Darling Basin</a> that were too heavy for the cultivation of fruit and too infertile for wheat.<sup id="cite_ref-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because irrigation water, despite the extremely low runoff of temperate Australia,<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> was (and remains) very cheap, the growing of rice was taken up by agricultural groups over the following decades. Californian varieties of rice were found suitable for the climate in the <a href="/wiki/Riverina" title="Riverina">Riverina</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246-69">[69]</a></sup> and the first mill opened at <a href="/wiki/Leeton,_New_South_Wales" title="Leeton, New South Wales">Leeton</a> in 1951.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ABS-5439.0-InternationalMerchandiseImportsAustralia-StandardInternationalTradeClassificationCustomsValue-042Rice-A1828736L.svg" title="File:ABS-5439.0-InternationalMerchandiseImportsAustralia-StandardInternationalTradeClassificationCustomsValue-042Rice-A1828736L.svg">File:ABS-5439.0-InternationalMerchandiseImportsAustralia-StandardInternationalTradeClassificationCustomsValue-042Rice-A1828736L.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Monthly value (<a href="/wiki/Australian_dollar" title="Australian dollar">A$ millions</a>) of rice imports to Australia since 1988</div></div></div>
<p>Even before this Australia's rice production greatly exceeded local needs,<sup id="cite_ref-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246_69-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wadham.2C_Sir_Samuel_p._246-69">[69]</a></sup> and rice exports to Japan have become a major source of foreign currency. Above-average rainfall from the 1950s to the middle 1990s<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> encouraged the expansion of the Riverina rice industry, but its prodigious water use in a practically waterless region began to attract the attention of environmental scientists. These became severely concerned with declining flow in the <a href="/wiki/Snowy_River" title="Snowy River">Snowy River</a> and the lower <a href="/wiki/Murray_River" title="Murray River">Murray River</a>.
</p><p>Although rice growing in Australia is highly profitable due to the cheapness of land, several recent years of severe drought have led many to call for its elimination because of its effects on extremely fragile aquatic ecosystems. The Australian rice industry is somewhat opportunistic, with the area planted varying significantly from season to season depending on water allocations in the <a href="/wiki/Murray_River" title="Murray River">Murray</a> and <a href="/wiki/Murrumbidgee_River" title="Murrumbidgee River">Murrumbidgee</a> irrigation regions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production_and_commerce">Production and commerce</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; clear:left;">

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
