</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RiceYield.png" title="File:RiceYield.png">File:RiceYield.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Worldwide rice production</div></div></div>
<p>Rice is a major food staple and a mainstay for the rural population and their food security. It is mainly cultivated by small farmers in holdings of less than 1 hectare. Rice is also a wage commodity for workers in the cash crop or non-agricultural sectors. Rice is vital for the nutrition of much of the population in Asia, as well as in Latin America and the Caribbean and in Africa; it is central to the food security of over half the world population. Developing countries account for 95% of the total production, with China and India alone responsible for nearly half of the world output.<sup id="cite_ref-FAORice1_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAORice1-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>World production of rice has risen steadily from about 200 million <a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a> of paddy rice in 1960 to over 678 million tonnes in 2009. The three largest producers of rice in 2009 were China (197 million tonnes), India (131 Mt), and Indonesia (64 Mt). Among the six largest rice producers, the most productive farms for rice, in 2009, were in China producing 6.59 tonnes per hectare.<sup id="cite_ref-OSU2009_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OSU2009-74">[74]</a></sup> At 44 million hectares, India had the largest farm area under rice production in 2009. The rice farm productivity in India were about 45% of the rice farm productivity in China, and about 60% of the rice farm productivity in Indonesia.
</p><p>If India could adopt the farming knowledge and technology in use in China and Indonesia, India could produce an additional 100 million tonnes of rice, enough staple food for about 400 million people every year, and US$50 billion in additional annual income to its rice farmers (adjusted to 2010 dollars and global rice prices per tonne). In the 1990s, genetic studies took place in many European laboratories to increase rice production per hectare. Most of them were Dutch agricultural organizations united by <a href="/w/index.php?title=HNGAC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HNGAC (page does not exist)">HNGAC</a>. These studies were later stopped due to lack of funding.
</p><p>In addition to the gap in farming system technology and knowledge, many rice grain producing countries have significant losses post-harvest at the farm and because of poor roads, inadequate storage technologies, inefficient supply chains and farmer's inability to bring the produce into retail markets dominated by small shopkeepers. A World Bank – FAO study claims 8% to 26% of rice is lost in developing nations, on average, every year, because of post-harvest problems and poor infrastructure. Some sources claim the post-harvest losses to exceed 40%.,<sup id="cite_ref-FAORice1_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAORice1-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>Not only do these losses reduce food security in the world, the study claims that farmers in developing countries such as China, India and others lose approximately US$89 billion of income in preventable post-harvest farm losses, poor transport, the lack of proper storage and retail. One study claims that if these post-harvest grain losses could be eliminated with better infrastructure and retail network, in India alone enough food would be saved every year to feed 70 to 100 million people over a year.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Harvesting.2C_drying_and_milling">Harvesting, drying and milling</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rice-combine-harvester,katori-city,japan.JPG" title="File:Rice-combine-harvester,katori-city,japan.JPG">File:Rice-combine-harvester,katori-city,japan.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rice combine harvester <a href="/w/index.php?title=Katori,_Chiba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Katori, Chiba (page does not exist)">Katori-city</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Unmilled rice, known as paddy (Indonesia and Malaysia: padi; Philippines, palay), is usually harvested when the grains have a moisture content of around 25%. In most Asian countries, where rice is almost entirely the product of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smallholder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smallholder (page does not exist)">smallholder</a> agriculture, harvesting is carried out manually, although there is a growing interest in mechanical harvesting. Harvesting can be carried out by the farmers themselves, but is also frequently done by seasonal labour groups. Harvesting is followed by <a href="/wiki/Threshing" title="Threshing">threshing</a>, either immediately or within a day or two. Again, much threshing is still carried out by hand but there is an increasing use of mechanical threshers. Subsequently, paddy needs to be dried to bring down the moisture content to no more than 20% for milling.
</p><p>A familiar sight in several Asian countries is paddy laid out to dry along roads. However, in most countries the bulk of drying of marketed paddy takes place in mills, with village-level drying being used for paddy to be consumed by farm families. Mills either sun dry or use mechanical driers or both. Drying has to be carried out quickly to avoid the formation of moulds. Mills range from simple <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_huller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice huller (page does not exist)">hullers</a>, with a throughput of a couple of tonnes a day, that simply remove the outer husk, to enormous operations that can process 4,000 tonnes a day and produce highly polished rice. A good mill can achieve a paddy-to-rice conversion rate of up to 72% but smaller, inefficient mills often struggle to achieve 60%. These smaller mills often do not buy paddy and sell rice but only service farmers who want to mill their paddy for their own consumption.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Distribution">Distribution</span></h3>
<p>Because of the importance of rice to human nutrition and food security in Asia, the domestic rice markets tend to be subject to considerable state involvement. While the private sector plays a leading role in most countries, agencies such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_Bureau_of_Logistics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian Bureau of Logistics (page does not exist)">BULOG</a> in Indonesia, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Food_Authority_(Philippines)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Food Authority (Philippines) (page does not exist)">NFA</a> in the Philippines, VINAFOOD in Vietnam and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_Corporation_of_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food Corporation of India (page does not exist)">Food Corporation of India</a> are all heavily involved in purchasing of paddy from farmers or rice from mills and in distributing rice to poorer people. BULOG and NFA monopolise rice imports into their countries while VINAFOOD controls all exports from Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">Trade</span></h3>
<p>World trade figures are very different to those for production, as less than 8% of rice produced is traded internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-cendrowski2013_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cendrowski2013-78">[78]</a></sup>  In economic terms, the global rice trade was a small fraction of 1% of world mercantile trade. Many countries consider rice as a strategic food staple, and various governments subject its trade to a wide range of controls and interventions.
</p><p>Developing countries are the main players in the world rice trade, accounting for 83% of exports and 85% of imports. While there are numerous importers of rice, the exporters of rice are limited. Just five countries – Thailand, Vietnam, China, the United States and India – in decreasing order of exported quantities, accounted for about three-quarters of world rice exports in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-FAORice1_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAORice1-73">[73]</a></sup> However, this ranking has been rapidly changing in recent years. In 2010, the three largest exporters of rice, in decreasing order of quantity exported were Thailand, Vietnam and India. By 2012, India became the largest exporter of rice with a 100% increase in its exports on year to year basis, and Thailand slipped to third position.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> Together, Thailand, Vietnam and India accounted for nearly 70% of the world rice exports.
</p><p>The primary variety exported by Thailand and Vietnam were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jasmine_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jasmine rice (page does not exist)">Jasmine rice</a>, while exports from India included aromatic <a href="/wiki/Basmati" title="Basmati">Basmati</a> variety. China, an exporter of rice in early 2000s, was a net importer of rice in 2010 and will become the largest net importer, surpassing Nigeria, in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-cendrowski2013_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cendrowski2013-78">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>  According to a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">USDA</a> report, the world's largest exporters of rice in 2012 were India (9.75 million tonnes), Vietnam (7 million tonnes), Thailand (6.5 million tonnes), Pakistan (3.75 million tonnes) and the United States (3.5 million tonnes).<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major importers usually include Nigeria, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Malaysia, the Philippines, Brazil and some African and <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> countries. Although China and India are the two largest producers of rice in the world, both countries consume the majority of the rice produced domestically, leaving little to be traded internationally.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World.27s_most_productive_rice_farms_and_farmers">World's most productive rice farms and farmers</span></h3>
<p>The average world yield for rice was 4.3 tonnes per hectare, in 2010.
</p><p>Australian rice farms were the most productive in 2010, with a nationwide average of 10.8 tonnes per hectare.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yuan Longping of China National Hybrid Rice Research and Development Center, China, set a world record for rice yield in 2010 at 19 tonnes per hectare on a demonstration plot. In 2011, this record was surpassed by an Indian farmer, Sumant Kumar, with 22.4 tonnes per hectare in Bihar. Both these farmers claim to have employed newly developed rice breeds and <a href="/w/index.php?title=System_of_Rice_Intensification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="System of Rice Intensification (page does not exist)">System of Rice Intensification</a> (SRI), a recent innovation in rice farming. SRI is claimed to have set new national records in rice yields, within the last 10 years, in many countries. The claimed Chinese and Indian yields have yet to be demonstrated on seven-hectare lots and to be reproducible over two consecutive years on the same farm.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Price">Price</span></h2>
<p>In late 2007 to May 2008, the price of grains rose greatly due to droughts in major producing countries (particularly Australia), increased use of grains for animal feed and US subsidies for bio-fuel production. Although there was no shortage of rice on world markets this general upward trend in grain prices led to panic buying by consumers, government rice export bans (in particular, by Vietnam and India) and inflated import orders by the Philippines marketing board, the National Food Authority. This caused significant rises in rice prices. In late April 2008, prices hit 24 <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_cent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US cent (page does not exist)">US cents</a> a <a href="/wiki/Pound_(mass)" title="Pound (mass)">pound</a>, twice the price of seven months earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-cyclone_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cyclone-88">[88]</a></sup>  Over the period of 2007 to 2013, the Chinese government has substantially increased the price it pays domestic farmers for their rice, rising to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> per metric ton by 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-cendrowski2013_78-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cendrowski2013-78">[78]</a></sup>  The 2013 price of rice originating from other southeast Asian countries was a comparably low <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> per metric ton.<sup id="cite_ref-cendrowski2013_78-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cendrowski2013-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 30, 2008, Thailand announced plans for the creation of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_of_Rice_Exporting_Countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation of Rice Exporting Countries (page does not exist)">Organisation of Rice Exporting Countries</a> (OREC) with the intention that this should develop into a price-fixing <a href="/wiki/Cartel" title="Cartel">cartel</a> for rice.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> However, little progress had been made by mid-2011 to achieve this.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Worldwide_consumption">Worldwide consumption</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; clear:left;">
<tr>
<th colspan="2">Food consumption of rice by country – 2009<br />(million metric ton of paddy equivalent)<sup id="cite_ref-con_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con-91">[91]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> World Total </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 531.6
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

<td style="text-align:center;"> 10.0
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td style="text-align:center;"> 5.8
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td style="text-align:center;"> 4.8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 4.6
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 4.3
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.8
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.5
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.4
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 3.1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Flagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Flagu (page does not exist)">Template:Flagu</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:center;"> 2.8
</td></tr></table>
<p>As of 2009 world food consumption of rice was 531.6 million metric tons of paddy equivalent (354,603 of milled equivalent), while the far largest consumers were China consuming 156.3 million metric tons of paddy equivalent (29.4% of the world consumption) and India consuming 123.5 million metric tons of paddy equivalent (23.3% of the world consumption).<sup id="cite_ref-con_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con-91">[91]</a></sup> Between 1961 and 2002, per capita consumption of rice increased by 40%.
</p><p>Rice is the most important crop in Asia. In Cambodia, for example, 90% of the total agricultural area is used for rice production.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>U.S. rice consumption has risen sharply over the past 25 years, fueled in part by commercial applications such as beer production.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> Almost one in five adult Americans now report eating at least half a serving of white or brown rice per day.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_impacts">Environmental impacts</span></h2>
<p>Rice cultivation on wetland rice fields is thought to be responsible for 1.5% of the anthropogenic methane emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Rice requires slightly more water to produce than other grains.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Long-term flooding of rice fields cuts the soil off from atmospheric oxygen and causes anaerobic fermentation of organic matter in the soil.<sup id="cite_ref-heinz_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heinz-97">[97]</a></sup> Methane production from rice cultivation contributes ~1.5% of anthropogenic greenhouse gases.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">Methane</a> is twenty times more potent a greenhouse gas than <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2010 study found that, as a result of rising temperatures and decreasing solar radiation during the later years of the 20th century, the rice yield growth rate has decreased in many parts of Asia, compared to what would have been observed had the temperature and solar radiation trends not occurred.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> The yield growth rate had fallen 10–20% at some locations. The study was based on records from 227 farms in Thailand, Vietnam, Nepal, India, China, Bangladesh, and Pakistan. The mechanism of this falling yield was not clear, but might involve increased respiration during warm nights, which expends energy without being able to photosynthesize.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Pests_and_diseases">Pests and diseases</span></h2>
<p>Rice pests are any <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organism (page does not exist)">organisms</a> or <a href="/wiki/Microbe" title="Microbe" class="mw-redirect">microbes</a> with the potential to reduce the yield or value of the rice crop (or of rice seeds).<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> Rice pests include weeds, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pathogen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pathogen (page does not exist)">pathogens</a>, insects, nematode, rodents, and birds. A variety of factors can contribute to pest outbreaks, including climatic factors, improper irrigation, the overuse of <a href="/wiki/Insecticides" title="Insecticides" class="mw-redirect">insecticides</a> and high rates of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nitrogen_fertilizer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nitrogen fertilizer (page does not exist)">nitrogen fertilizer</a> application.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Weather conditions also contribute to pest outbreaks. For example, rice <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gall_midge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gall midge (page does not exist)">gall midge</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Army_worm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Army worm (page does not exist)">army worm</a> outbreaks tend to follow periods of high rainfall early in the wet season, while <a href="/wiki/Thrips" title="Thrips">thrips</a> outbreaks are associated with drought.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Insects">Insects</span></h3>
<p>Major rice insect pests include: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brown_planthopper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brown planthopper (page does not exist)">brown planthopper</a> (BPH),<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> several spp. of stemborers - including those in the genera <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Scirpophaga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scirpophaga (page does not exist)">Scirpophaga</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chilo_suppressalis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chilo suppressalis (page does not exist)">Chilo</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> the rice <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gall_midge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gall midge (page does not exist)">gall midge</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> several spp. of rice bugs<sup id="cite_ref-j1_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j1-108">[108]</a></sup> - notably in the genus <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Leptocorisa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leptocorisa (page does not exist)">Leptocorisa</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cnaphalocrocis_medinalis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cnaphalocrocis medinalis (page does not exist)">rice leafroller</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_weevil&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice weevil (page does not exist)">rice weevils</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diseases">Diseases</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Rice_blast" title="Rice blast" class="mw-redirect">Rice blast</a>, caused by the fungus <i>Magnaporthe grisea</i>, is the most significant disease affecting rice cultivation. Other major rice diseases include: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rhizoctonia_solani&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rhizoctonia solani (page does not exist)">sheath blight</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_ragged_stunt_virus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice ragged stunt virus (page does not exist)">rice ragged stunt</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Vector_(epidemiology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vector (epidemiology) (page does not exist)">vector</a>: BPH), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tungro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tungro (page does not exist)">tungro</a> (vector: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nephotettix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nephotettix (page does not exist)">Nephotettix</a></i> spp).<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> There is also an <a href="/wiki/Ascomycete" title="Ascomycete" class="mw-redirect">ascomycete</a> fungus, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cochliobolus_miyabeanus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cochliobolus miyabeanus (page does not exist)">Cochliobolus miyabeanus</a></i>, that causes brown spot disease in rice.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nematodes">Nematodes</span></h3>
<p>Several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nematode&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nematode (page does not exist)">nematode</a> species infect rice crops, causing diseases such as Ufra (Ditylenchus dipsaci), White tip disease (Aphelenchoide bessei), and root knot disease (Meloidogyne graminicola). Some nematode species such as <i>Pratylenchus</i> spp. are most dangerous in upland rice of all parts of the world. Rice root nematode (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hirschmanniella_oryzae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hirschmanniella oryzae (page does not exist)">Hirschmanniella oryzae</a></i>) is a migratory endoparasite which on higher inoculum levels will lead to complete destruction of a rice crop. Beyond being obligate parasites, they also decrease the vigor of plants and increase the plants' susceptibility to other pests and diseases.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_Pests">Other Pests</span></h3>
<p>These include: the apple snail  <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pomacea_canaliculata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pomacea canaliculata (page does not exist)">Pomacea canaliculata</a></i>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panicle_rice_mite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panicle rice mite (page does not exist)">panicle rice mite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rat" title="Rat">rats</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> and the weed <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Echinochloa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Echinochloa (page does not exist)">Echinochloa</a> crusgali</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Integrated_Pest_Management"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Integrated_Pest_Management&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Integrated Pest Management (page does not exist)">Integrated Pest Management</a></span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Crop_protection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crop protection (page does not exist)">Crop protection</a> scientists are trying to develop rice pest management techniques which are <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_agriculture" title="Sustainable agriculture">sustainable</a>. In other words, to manage crop pests in such a manner that future crop production is not threatened.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> Sustainable pest management is based on four principles: biodiversity, host plant resistance (HPR), landscape ecology, and hierarchies in a landscape – from biological to social.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> At present, rice pest management includes cultural techniques, pest-resistant rice varieties, and <a href="/wiki/Pesticides" title="Pesticides" class="mw-redirect">pesticides</a> (which include <a href="/wiki/Insecticide" title="Insecticide">insecticide</a>). Increasingly, there is evidence that farmers' pesticide applications are often unnecessary, and even facilitate pest outbreaks.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> By reducing the populations of natural enemies of rice pests,<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> misuse of insecticides can actually lead to pest outbreaks.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> (IRRI) demonstrated in 1993 that an 87.5% reduction in pesticide use can lead to an overall drop in pest numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> IRRI also conducted two campaigns in 1994 and 2003, respectively, which discouraged insecticide misuse and smarter pest management in Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rice plants produce their own chemical defenses to protect themselves from pest attacks. Some synthetic chemicals, such as the herbicide 2,4-D, cause the plant to increase the production of certain defensive chemicals and thereby increase the plant’s resistance to some types of pests.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> Conversely, other chemicals, such as the insecticide imidacloprid, can induce changes in the gene expression of the rice that cause the plant to become more susceptible to attacks by certain types of pests.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>  5-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Alkylresorcinol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alkylresorcinol (page does not exist)">Alkylresorcinols</a> are chemicals that can also be found in rice.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
Botanicals, so-called "natural pesticides", are used by some farmers in an attempt to control rice pests. Botanicals include extracts of leaves, or a mulch of the leaves themselves. Some upland rice farmers in Cambodia spread chopped leaves of the bitter bush (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chromolaena_odorata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chromolaena odorata (page does not exist)">Chromolaena odorata</a></i>) over the surface of fields after planting. This practice probably helps the soil retain moisture and thereby facilitates seed germination. Farmers also claim the leaves are a natural fertilizer and helps suppress weed and insect infestations.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>  <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chloroxylon_from_India.JPG" title="File:Chloroxylon from India.JPG">File:Chloroxylon from India.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chloroxylon is used for Pest Management in Organic Rice Cultivation in Chhattisgarh, India</div></div></div>
<p>Among rice cultivars, there are differences in the responses to, and recovery from, pest damage.<sup id="cite_ref-j1_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j1-108">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Many rice varieties have been selected for resistance to insect pests.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Therefore, particular cultivars are recommended for areas prone to certain pest problems. The genetically based ability of a rice variety to withstand pest attacks is called resistance. Three main types of plant resistance to pests are recognized as nonpreference, antibiosis, and tolerance.<sup id="cite_ref-j2_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j2-133">[133]</a></sup> Nonpreference (or antixenosis) describes host plants which insects prefer to avoid; antibiosis is where insect survival is reduced after the ingestion of host tissue; and tolerance is the capacity of a plant to produce high yield or retain high quality despite <a href="/w/index.php?title=Home_stored_product_entomology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Home stored product entomology (page does not exist)">insect infestation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over time, the use of pest resistant rice varieties selects for pests that are able to overcome these mechanisms of resistance. When a rice variety is no longer able to resist pest infestations, resistance is said to have broken down. Rice varieties that can be widely grown for many years in the presence of pests and retain their ability to withstand the pests are said to have durable resistance. Mutants of popular rice varieties are regularly screened by plant breeders to discover new sources of durable resistance.<sup id="cite_ref-j2_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j2-133">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parasitic_weeds">Parasitic weeds</span></h3>
<p>Rice is parasitized by the weed <a href="/wiki/Eudicot" title="Eudicot" class="mw-redirect">eudicot</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Striga_hermonthica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Striga hermonthica (page does not exist)">Striga hermonthica</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> which is of local importance for this crop.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultivars">Cultivars</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rice_diversity.jpg" title="File:Rice diversity.jpg">File:Rice diversity.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rice seed collection from <a href="/wiki/IRRI" title="IRRI" class="mw-redirect">IRRI</a></div></div></div>
<p>While most rice is bred for crop quality and productivity, there are varieties selected for characteristics such as texture, smell, and firmness. Cultivars exist that are adapted to deep flooding, and these are generally called "floating rice".<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are four major categories of rice worldwide: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indica_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indica rice (page does not exist)">indica</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japonica_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japonica rice (page does not exist)">japonica</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aromatic_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aromatic rice (page does not exist)">aromatic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Glutinous_rice" title="Glutinous rice">glutinous</a>. The different varieties of rice are not considered interchangeable, either in food preparation or agriculture, so as a result, each major variety is a completely separate market from other varieties. It is common for one variety of rice to rise in price while another one drops in price.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>The largest collection of rice cultivars is at the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> in the Philippines, with over 100,000 rice accessions<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> held in the International Rice Genebank.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Rice <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivars</a> are often classified by their grain shapes and texture. For example, Thai <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jasmine_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jasmine rice (page does not exist)">Jasmine rice</a> is long-grain and relatively less sticky, as some long-grain rice contains less <a href="/wiki/Amylopectin" title="Amylopectin">amylopectin</a> than short-grain cultivars. Chinese restaurants often serve long-grain as plain unseasoned steamed rice though short-grain rice is common as well. Japanese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mochigome&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mochigome (page does not exist)">mochi rice</a> and Chinese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sticky_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sticky rice (page does not exist)">sticky rice</a> are short-grain. Chinese people use sticky rice which is properly known as "glutinous rice" (note: glutinous refer to the glue-like characteristic of rice; does not refer to "gluten") to make <a href="/wiki/Zongzi" title="Zongzi">zongzi</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese rice (page does not exist)">Japanese table rice</a> is a sticky, short-grain rice. Japanese <a href="/wiki/Sake" title="Sake">sake</a> rice is another kind as well.
</p><p>Indian rice cultivars include long-grained and aromatic <a href="/wiki/Basmati" title="Basmati">Basmati</a> (ਬਾਸਮਤੀ) (grown in the North), long and medium-grained <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patna_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patna rice (page does not exist)">Patna rice</a>, and in South India (<a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>) short-grained <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sona_Masuri&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sona Masuri (page does not exist)">Sona Masuri</a> (also called as Bangaru theegalu). In the state of Tamil Nadu, the most prized cultivar is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ponni_Rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ponni Rice (page does not exist)"><i>ponni</i></a> which is primarily grown in the delta regions of the <a href="/wiki/Kaveri" title="Kaveri">Kaveri</a> River. <a href="/wiki/Kaveri" title="Kaveri">Kaveri</a> is also referred to as ponni in the South and the name reflects the geographic region where it is grown. In the Western Indian state of <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>, a short grain variety called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ambemohar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ambemohar (page does not exist)">Ambemohar</a> is very popular. This rice has a characteristic fragrance of Mango blossom.
</p><p>Aromatic rices have definite aromas and flavors; the most noted cultivars are Thai fragrant rice, Basmati, Patna rice, Vietnamese fragrant rice, and a <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">hybrid</a> cultivar from America, sold under the trade name Texmati. Both Basmati and Texmati have a mild <a href="/wiki/Popcorn" title="Popcorn">popcorn</a>-like aroma and flavor. In Indonesia, there are also <i>red</i> and <i>black</i> cultivars.
</p><p>High-yield cultivars of rice suitable for cultivation in Africa and other dry <a href="/wiki/Ecosystems" title="Ecosystems" class="mw-redirect">ecosystems</a>, called the <a href="/wiki/New_Rice_for_Africa" title="New Rice for Africa">new rice for Africa</a> (NERICA) cultivars, have been developed. It is hoped that their cultivation will improve <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a> in West Africa.
</p><p>Draft <a href="/wiki/Genomes" title="Genomes" class="mw-redirect">genomes</a> for the two most common rice cultivars, <i>indica</i> and <i>japonica</i>, were published in April 2002. Rice was chosen as a <a href="/wiki/Model_organism" title="Model organism">model organism</a> for the biology of grasses because of its relatively small genome (~430 mega<a href="/wiki/Base_pairs" title="Base pairs" class="mw-redirect">base pairs</a>). Rice was the first crop with a complete genome sequence.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 16, 2002, the <a href="/wiki/UN_General_Assembly" title="UN General Assembly" class="mw-redirect">UN General Assembly</a> declared the year 2004 the International Year of Rice. The declaration was sponsored by more than 40 countries.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biotechnology">Biotechnology</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="High-yielding_varieties">High-yielding varieties</span></h3>
<p>The high-yielding varieties are a group of crops created intentionally during the <a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution" title="Green Revolution">Green Revolution</a> to increase global food production. This project enabled labor markets in Asia to shift away from agriculture, and into industrial sectors. The first "Rice Car", IR8 was produced in 1966 at the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> which is based in the Philippines at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">University of the Philippines</a>' Los Baños site. IR8 was created through a cross between an Indonesian variety named "Peta" and a Chinese variety named "Dee Geo Woo Gen."<sup id="cite_ref-ir8_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ir8-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>Scientists have identified and cloned many genes involved in the <a href="/wiki/Gibberellin" title="Gibberellin">gibberellin</a> signaling pathway, including GAI1 (<a href="/wiki/Gibberellin" title="Gibberellin">Gibberellin</a> Insensitive) and SLR1 (Slender Rice).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> Disruption of <a href="/wiki/Gibberellin" title="Gibberellin">gibberellin</a> signaling can lead to significantly reduced stem growth leading to a dwarf phenotype. Photosynthetic investment in the stem is reduced dramatically as the shorter plants are inherently more stable mechanically. Assimilates become redirected to grain production, amplifying in particular the effect of chemical fertilizers on commercial yield. In the presence of nitrogen fertilizers, and intensive crop management, these varieties increase their yield two to three times.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_potential">Future potential</span></h3>
<p>As the UN Millennium Development project seeks to spread global economic development to Africa, the "Green Revolution" is cited as the model for economic development. With the intent of replicating the successful Asian boom in agronomic productivity, groups like the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earth_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earth Institute (page does not exist)">Earth Institute</a> are doing research on African agricultural systems, hoping to increase productivity. An important way this can happen is the production of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Rices_for_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Rices for Africa (page does not exist)">New Rices for Africa</a>" (NERICA). These rices, selected to tolerate the low input and harsh growing conditions of African agriculture, are produced by the African Rice Center, and billed as technology "from Africa, for Africa". The NERICA have appeared in <i>The New York Times</i> (October 10, 2007) and <i>International Herald Tribune</i> (October 9, 2007), trumpeted as miracle crops that will dramatically increase rice yield in Africa and enable an economic resurgence. Ongoing research in China to develop <a href="/w/index.php?title=Perennial_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Perennial rice (page does not exist)">perennial rice</a> could result in enhanced sustainability and <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Golden_rice">Golden rice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Rice kernels do not contain <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_A" title="Vitamin A">vitamin A</a>, so people who obtain most of their calories from rice are at risk of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_A_deficiency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin A deficiency (page does not exist)">vitamin A deficiency</a>. German and Swiss researchers have <a href="/wiki/Genetic_engineering" title="Genetic engineering">genetically engineered</a> rice to produce <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beta-carotene&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beta-carotene (page does not exist)">beta-carotene</a>, the precursor to vitamin A, in the rice kernel. The beta-carotene turns the processed (white) rice a "gold" color, hence the name "golden rice." The beta-carotene is converted to vitamin A in humans who consume the rice.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Although some rice strains produce beta-carotene in the hull, no non-genetically engineered strains have been found that produce beta-carotene in the kernel, despite the testing of thousands of strains. Additional efforts are being made to improve the quantity and quality of other nutrients in golden rice.<sup id="cite_ref-gcgh_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gcgh-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> is currently further developing and evaluating Golden Rice as a potential new way to help address vitamin A deficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Expression_of_human_proteins">Expression of human proteins</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ventria_Bioscience" title="Ventria Bioscience">Ventria Bioscience</a> has <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified" title="Genetically modified" class="mw-redirect">genetically modified</a> rice to <a href="/wiki/Gene_expression" title="Gene expression">express</a> <a href="/wiki/Lactoferrin" title="Lactoferrin">lactoferrin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lysozyme" title="Lysozyme">lysozyme</a> which are <a href="/wiki/Proteins" title="Proteins" class="mw-redirect">proteins</a> usually found in <a href="/wiki/Breast_milk" title="Breast milk">breast milk</a>., and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_serum_albumin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human serum albumin (page does not exist)">human serum albumin</a>, These proteins have <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antiviral_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antiviral protein (page does not exist)">antiviral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antibacterial" title="Antibacterial">antibacterial</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antifungal_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antifungal protein (page does not exist)">antifungal</a> effects.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rice containing these added proteins can be used as a component in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oral_rehydration_solution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oral rehydration solution (page does not exist)">oral rehydration solutions</a> which are used to treat <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrheal</a> diseases, thereby shortening their duration and reducing recurrence. Such supplements may also help reverse <a href="/wiki/Anemia" title="Anemia">anemia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flood_tolerant_rice">Flood tolerant rice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Flooding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flooding (page does not exist)">Flooding</a> is an issue that many rice growers face, especially in South and <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South East Asia (page does not exist)">South East Asia</a> where flooding annually affects 20 million hectares.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup> Standard rice varieties cannot withstand stagnant flooding of more than about a week,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> mainly as it disallows the plant access to necessary requirements such as sunlight and essential gas exchanges, inevitably leading to plants being unable to recover.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup> 
In the past, this has led to a massive losses in yields, such as in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, where in 2006, rice crops worth $65 million were lost to flooding.
<sup id="cite_ref-:1_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>In response to this hazard, a variety of rice named Swarna Sub1 was developed via <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marker-assisted_selection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marker-assisted selection (page does not exist)">marker-assisted selection</a>, with the ability to withstand prolonged periods of around 14 days beneath a flooded plain.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_152-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-152">[152]</a></sup> The submergence tolerance ability of this variety is conferred by the presence of the Sub1A gene, introgressed from the Indian cultivar FR13A into the flood-vulnerable (but high yielding) cultivar Swarna.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_152-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-152">[152]</a></sup> 
Swarna Sub1 effectively enters a dormant, energy conserving state upon being submerged in a flooded rice paddy, a process that involves the finely controlled <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolism</a> of <a href="/wiki/Enzymes" title="Enzymes" class="mw-redirect">enzymes</a> such <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amylases&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amylases (page does not exist)">amylases</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Starch_phosphorylase&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Starch phosphorylase (page does not exist)">starch phosphorylase</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_dehydrogenase" title="Alcohol dehydrogenase">alcohol dehydrogenase</a>, allowing the plant to survive with limited oxygen and sunlight unlike its standard variety relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_152-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-152">[152]</a></sup> 
Given that the presence of the Sub1A gene does not impact upon the quality or quantity of the rice obtained,<sup id="cite_ref-:0_150-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-150">[150]</a></sup> 
this variety has been very popular, with 1.7 million hectares of land in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> having Swarna Sub1 and other flood resistant varieties used instead of conventional rice crops.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Drought_tolerant_rice">Drought tolerant rice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Drought" title="Drought">Drought</a> represents a significant environmental stress for rice production, with 19-23 million hectares of rainfed rice production in South and South East Asia often at risk.<sup id="cite_ref-irri.org_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irri.org-154">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:2_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-155">[155]</a></sup> Under drought conditions, without sufficient water to afford them the ability to obtain the required levels of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nutrients&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nutrients (page does not exist)">nutrients</a> from the soil, conventional commercial rice varieties can be severely impacted – for example yield losses as high as 40% have affected some parts of India, with resulting losses of around USD $800 million annually.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a> (IRRI) conducts research into developing drought tolerant rice varieties, including the varieties 5411 and Sookha dhan, currently being employed by farmers in the Philippines and Nepal respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-155">[155]</a></sup> In addition, in 2013 the Japanese National Institute for Agrobiological Sciences led a team which successfully inserted the DEEPER ROOTING 1 (DRO1), from the Philippine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Upland_and_lowland_(freshwater_ecology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Upland and lowland (freshwater ecology) (page does not exist)">upland</a> rice variety Kinandang Patong, into the popular commercial rice variety IR64, giving rise to a far deeper root system in the resulting plants.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_156-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-156">[156]</a></sup> 
This facilitates an improved ability for the rice plant to derive its required nutrients in times of drought via accessing deeper layers of <a href="/wiki/Soil" title="Soil">soil</a>, a feature demonstrated by trials which saw the IR64 + DRO1 rice yields drop by 10% under moderate drought conditions, compared to 60% for the unmodified IR64 variety.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_156-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-156">[156]</a></sup>
<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salt_tolerant_rice">Salt tolerant rice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Soil_salinity" title="Soil salinity">Soil salinity</a> poses a major threat to rice crop productivity, particularly along low-lying coastal areas during the dry season<sup id="cite_ref-irri.org_154-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irri.org-154">[154]</a></sup> 
- for example, roughly 1 million hectares of the coastal areas of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> are affected by saline soils.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> 
These high concentrations of salt can severely impact upon rice plants’ normal <a href="/wiki/Physiology" title="Physiology">physiology</a>, especially during early stages of growth, and as such farmers are often forced to abandon these otherwise potentially usable areas.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Progress has been made, however, in developing rice varieties capable of tolerating such conditions; the hybrid created from the cross between the commercial rice variety IR56 and the wild rice species <i>Oryza coarctata</i> is one example.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-161">[161]</a></sup> <i>O. coarctata</i> is capable of successful growth in soils with double the limit of salinity of normal varieties, but lacks the ability to produce edible rice.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-161">[161]</a></sup>
Developed by the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">hybrid</a> variety can utilise specialised leaf glands that allow for the removal of salt into the atmosphere. It was initially produced from one successful <a href="/wiki/Embryo" title="Embryo">embryo</a> out of 34,000 crosses between the two species; this was then <a href="/wiki/Backcrossing" title="Backcrossing">backcrossed</a> to IR56 with the aim of preserving the genes responsible for salt tolerance that were inherited from <i>O. coarctata</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_159-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-159">[159]</a></sup> 
Furthermore, extensive trials are planned prior to the new variety being available to farmers by approximately 2017-18.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_159-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col end (page does not exist)">Template:Div col end</a>

</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.havanatimes.org/?p=25078">A Cuban Skirmish for Rice</a> by Isbel Diaz Torres, <i>Havana Times</i>, June 16, 2010

</li>

</li>

</li>
